info.title: Custom Fonts in CSS
info.text: This example shows how to use the @import and @font-face CSS rules to use custom fonts on your website from both a remote file and local file.

info.title: @import Rule
info.text: Here we are using the @import rule to load an external font from Google Fonts. Google Fonts will give you code snippets that you can copy and paste into your CSS. In this example, we are importing the Bungee Shade font by passing the Google Font link to the CSS url function.

info.title: @font-face Rule
info.text:
Here we are using the @font-face rule to load a font that is stored locally. First we name our font using the font-family property, in this case it's called cyberdyne because that's the name of the font. This can be any name you like though. Then we need to use the src property to point to the cyberdyne.ttf font file stored in the css/fonts directory of our website.

You can find a ton of free to use fonts from sites like Dafont or Font Squirrel and ttf or woff font file types will both work.

If you copy and paste the Google Font url from the previous step in a new browser window, you'll see that it will import similar @font-face rules into our CSS.

info.title: Font Classes
info.text:
Next we need to make classes that we can use with elements in our HTML code that will load the font on our page.

The first class called .bungee-shade uses the font-family property, but this CSS came from Google Fonts. As stated in step 1, Google Fonts will give you code snippets that you can copy and paste into your CSS.

The second class called .cyberdyne also uses the font-family property in order to use the Cyberdyne font. This font-family name needs to exactly match the font-family name you gave your font in step 3.

info.title: Displaying Google Font
info.text: In this step we are adding the bungee-shade class to our h1 element to display the Bungee Shade Google Font.

info.title: Displaying Local Font
info.text: In this step we are adding the cyberdyne class to our h1 element to display the Cyberdyne font stored locally.
